text: thank you it's a great pleasure to be back here I think I gave a talk to a few years ago on behavioral change I like to
think of topics that are topical and I think big data has been something that
has been around for a number of years but I think what we're seeing is the emergence of what I'm calling creepy
data and so my talk is going to be covering some of that and saying that there are alternative ways by which we
can think about how we collect data how it's used and in particular personal
data how how the general public can be made more aware of it and perhaps even
find it useful so what methods might we use to discover what people really think
about data that's being collected about them we can ask them or we can ask them
to fill in surveys but I think one approach that is perhaps we could try
and use is well as called breaching experiments and these are originally
developed by sociologists no less Goffman of garfinkel and a breaching
experiment the idea is to disrupt the accepted code of conduct and unstated social norms and
so some of the original experiments that were conducted in the 70s were to sit
right next to someone when there are plenty of empty tables in a cafe I don't know if any of you have done that or had
that experience or whether it's in a train and or that you're going around
the the supermarket with your cart and someone comes along and takes something
out of your cart and puts it into theirs these are what are called breaching experiments they're going against and what's normally accepted behavior and
the idea is to observe people's reactions so when this happens do they become upset do they pretend it hasn't
happened do they move do they get surprised or do they even get outraged
and so this sort of gets people to on the spot if you like and and even do
they question the reality of the situation so these kinds of breaching
experiments were done in the 70 social psychologist Stanley Milgram also conducted some of these but I think it's
an appropriate method to think about how we can get people to think about what data is being collected about them and
whether they feel comfortable or uncomfortable about this so a few years
ago a couple of my researchers went to a chi workshop which was looking at the
Internet of Things and how you might engage communities and they didn't have
enough time to build something so they thought they would do a breaching experiment and it was at the time when
quantified self was all the rage you know how can we measure ourselves and how can we use that data what would we
use it for and what they were interested in was could we do a quantified community not just about yourself but
could we measure everything or measure something about the community at large and so they set themselves up as a
fictitious can they set themselves up as
a fictitious company and they wanted to see what people would do by running this
breeching experiment so basically rather than quantified self they set themselves up as quantified toilets and the idea
was that they would install a urine analysis technology in the public toilets to improve public health and
they wanted to spark a debate about surveillance technologies how would people react knowing that when they went
to the toilets their urine was going to be analyzed for all sorts of things in the name of understanding better more
about that community and would they would they react badly would they accept
it so what did they do they had two days to do this to run this they came up with
this signage which says simply that this facility is proud to persist participate
in the healthy building initiative behavior are at these toilets is being
recorded for analysis and they put these stickers up in all of the toilets in the
convention center in Toronto and you could go to that website and find out about what was happening
and the narrative was that it would be for the benefits of society if this data could be collected because they'd have a
better understanding of the health of that particular community so they set up
this fake website and that website is still there I was surprised to see but if you can look at it it shows the time
the identification of the toilets the sex of the person who went to the toilet at that time how much they deposited the
odor whether there was any blood alcohol was whether there are any drugs detected
whether they were pregnant and any infections so to make it even more
authentic they said they provided a table at this website and it showed all
of the great things that this new system could do compared to other urine analysis so what do you think happened
well within a day everyone had heard about it people tweeted about it within
minutes and then it got retweeted the conference started there was outrage some people really thought it was the
case that this new system was being introduced hi there James and but what
we've what they found and I think this is what was interesting about using a breaching experiment was a wide range of
reactions to this so some as you might expect showed strong disapproval which
is health advice it does not get any creepier some showed concern for example
imagine your employer could find out how hard you'd partied last night others
showed resignation well I'm sure the government have been collecting this data for years others were more
voyeuristic and saying I just spent the last 10 minutes watching the pee pee locks can't stop watching them and then
there was humor some people tried to match people entering and exiting the toilets with the data appearing on the
website so you wouldn't have got this range of reactions if you just asked people what did he think if we
introduced this urine analysis system into all of our public toilets so we get
a better sense of public health and so we also found that local media or
rather the as well as being tweeted and retweeted it a number of journalists got
interested in an article appeared in the Atlantic with my title of my talk this
week the Washington Post were knocking on my inbox to ask me would I talk about
this talk to them but that's another story anyway I think what this breaching
experiment has shown is that you can get quite a different set of reactions unfortunately we've been unable to
publish this work because we didn't follow the IRB ethics procedure and so
even though this paper was submitted to CAI and got top marks by only reviewers because it suggested that it helps us
think about based on personal data in a very different way the the ACM reviewers
rather the ACM program committee felt that they couldn't publish it because we
hadn't followed the procedures but that's another story okay um so that's one approach by which
we can start to investigate and analyze how data is being collected about us some of you might be aware that there's
a big thing happening called AI and one aspect of this is emotional ai and we
now know that there are lots of startup companies who are interested in in analyzing people's facial expressions
with a view to understanding the emotional state that underlies these so
now in a number of stores faces of shoppers are being taken by their cameras and converted into biometric
templates and this is used primarily or allegedly for matching the well-known
shoplifters so that's how these cameras got set up and were accepted but once in
place they can be used for other things and now a number of companies are looking at how long you look at
something whether it's an advert or whether it's a piece of lingerie or whatever and your responses to products
machine learning is being used as well to class five people who are looking in milliseconds as to their gender their
age and they're assumed emotional state and retailers saying well there's
nothing wrong with this what's wrong with us collecting data like this after all we online shopping has been
collecting data about people's preferences about their clicks using cookies and a be testing for a number of
years and no one's really argued against that although when cookies first came out there was a lot of arguments about
whether or not we should be doing this so that's what's happening in stores so
um the question that I'm raising is our shop is comfortable with this kind of
physical tracking because they don't know it's happening they're not aware that this is happening and the same
thing is now happening with emotional emotional AI during job interviews as a
startup company in London called human and they came into being in 2016 and
they argue that they can detect subliminal facial expressions those
little micro twitches are in your face that you make and from this they can
calculate how honest how nervous and how passionate an applicant is when they're
answering specific had types of questions a hiring company for example a
Stanford might specify what they're looking for I know there's admit going
on this this weekend it might specify that what we want are students who are curious and creative nothing wrong with
that um and human can come along and take video footage of the various
students or whoever's here and do data capture analysis and compile a report on
each candidate the hiring company can then match the results with other HR
data that they might have already on them so in this sense no one needs to be
responsible for the ethics since the company is just doing this it's been asked to they're not making a decision
about whether this candidate is appropriate or not based on that the person who is the one that perhaps
is not cast and whether they would find it comfortable is the interviewee they
are not aware that this is happening so imagine you're sitting there having your yes well I'm going to come up to that
but yes if they all wear companies that make you pee in a cover to do a drug
test and you know you're aware of it you got to go pee in the car and and maybe
you decide I don't want to work for a company that's gonna make that decision based on this and is that the right way
to deal with this or I'm not saying it's the right way I'm just saying that this is happening and we as HCI researchers
maybe we need to think a bit more about are there ways in which we can conduct research to see whether people are
comfortable about this maybe it could be that people would feel comfortable if
the interview interviewers were also asked to have their facial expressions
analyzed so it became a instead of it just a one-way process so my point here
is to say that this type of data is becoming increasingly possible I'm not
saying it's right or wrong but we have maybe as a result as researchers have a responsibility to think about how
acceptable how is this out do people feel comfortable sure you could say well I don't want to go to Stanford because
they're using that method but maybe staff is the best place to come to study something and so you are being denied
going to somewhere because the institution is deciding to use this so
yeah I think that's there so this is what I'm calling the creepy dilemma that
personalized data collection is on the rise and there will be other ways in which AI is being used and I'm not
saying if this is good or bad I think you know it can be used for very good applications but there'll be ever more
claims being made and promulgated about how AI is better than human intelligence
so that company's human claim that they can analyze the micro risk expressions
in ways that we as humans are unable to notice and for not to infer the emotions that people
have and so what might happen is that what I'm calling a data divide will
emerge from those who are doing tracking the data and those being tracked and it
raises societal concerns about what my PhD student Lydia Nicholas has said is
neurological privacy this is something that you know it's inferring what's
happening your emotions your intent from your facial expressions that you may not
have control or understand yourself and this brings me on to the the the
second part of my talk which is are there other approaches that we as HCI or
social scientists can suggest where it embraces the data that's been collected
and it's open and it's transparent and that people are willingly agreed to
participate in the collecting of that data rather than it being unwittingly
being collected about them and that they feel comfortable doing so and this is
what last five years part of the project research that we've been doing which has
been funded by Intel which is called the interdisciplinary collaboration Research
Institute and we've been looking at in IOT technology sustainable and connected
cities and how we might use sensors in the environment and with people to
collect data and what we might do with it this is just one strand of the researchers many of you know Intel have funded many centers one of which was in
London between ourselves at UCL and Imperial so within the context of my
talk our starting point when thinking about this is sensing data has never
been easier anyone can go out and get a sensor and measure all sorts of things about environment or about your body but
can we make this sense data more accessible to the general public and if so how do we engage people in making
sense of it so this is our lab here in the picture of people who were working on the Intel I CRI
so our approach having thought about this is to try and think of ways in which we can open up the data how do we
reveal data to the general public that's what's being collected about them their
local environment and where they go can we trigger curiosity rather than
mistrust or fear why is that data being collected where is it going what's it
going to be useful and can we engage them in consciously contributing to the
data rather than it being subliminally collected and part of our approach is to
try and design very visible technology by this I mean physical technology that
people can notice and see what's being collected about them so I'm going to go
through three case studies where we have developed different ways of collecting data and analyzing it and importantly
engaging the general public in that collection these are data about Society
data that's collected in your home and thirdly data that's collected about tourism so the first one is about the
census every ten years in all countries in the world data is required it's
mandatory you have to fill in one of these questionnaires about that says all
sorts of things about your demographics about your beliefs about how much you're earning and the reason for this
collecting this data is so that governments can work out what's the best way to distribute funds and plan
services for a community be a housing transportation industry hospitals and so
on and in the u.s. your next one is in 2020 and apparently it's mandated by
article 1 section 2 of the Constitution and it also determines the number of
seats each state has in US House of Representatives however this thing that's been happening
for the last 100 years or so it hasn't changed in terms of the instrument that's being used apart from
going online in some countries the same questions are being asked all about demographics
and also you fill this in you don't really know where the data goes or if
you really are inquisitive you can go online and try and find a PDF from the
last one but it doesn't really necessarily help you it's designed primarily for governments so we were
asked by a working team in the UK in London who are interested in opening up
the census a bit more to think differently about how we might collect data about society and where it might go
we weren't asked to replace it but to think about additional ways of doing that and in particular we were asked to
use innovative technology and to think rather than just this online survey
we're also asked to think about how we might address the public good by this it
means referring to services like houses parks libraries and the such which
provided by the government for the community at large so that everyone can
benefit but to do this we were asked to think about what information would
people be prepared to give towards the public good in terms of the innovative technology as
I said we design something that was very visible rather than it being just another app or online survey and we
designed these physical installations we've done a number of these which was that these would appear in the public
and that people would see them notice them and approach them and maybe interact with them so we designed a
number of these which are were designed at waist level that people could go along and answer questions on a variety
of topics and that there would be a certain degree of privacy so that people
couldn't hear over and see what you were doing and some of the topics were to do with health city life trust been a lot a
sense of belongingness and these questions and themes were discussed at length with the working party who wanted
to change the way in which we ask questions of society and we asked three types of questions the first were direct
questions questions about health for example what blood group are you do you
give blood have you had unprotected and there were a number of answers which they could select the second set of
questions were to do with how would you mind sharing this the answers you give
with different types of people and these would be would you mind sharing your answer with close friends and family
with the City Council or the general public at large so example questions
here it might be does your mood change throughout the day do you have any hereditary conditions how many times did
you visit your doctor in the last year and third type of question was what
would you like to know about other people and people who live in your street or the community so some example
questions were who's living alone in your street your friend's whereabouts throughout the day and which local
services are most used in your neighborhood and so the way in which people could answer these was through
using this new kind of physical interface and we wanted to give feedback to people that they had actually
selected an answer so we had used sliders and buttons and dials and
buttons that could light up to show which answer you'd selected so after you
selected your answer it stayed put where it was so the next person who came along could see what answer you gave we were
interested to see whether people would find that an invasion of their privacy ie they might move the slider back or
whether they didn't really mind um they were given a smart card by which to put
into each of these boxes and the answers would be recorded on that so that they could then use those answers to compare
with other people's so the way in which it worked was that they would walk into this room take a card
answer questions on these different themes and then in the middle of the room was a what we call a visualization
station where they could put their card in and they could see their answers relative to what other people had
answered so you could get a way of comparison comparing rather and the data
was presented in simple a canonical form so for example here how many people have
unprotected sex you could see at that particular time what the answers were and how many people are organ donors
again at the time it was just before Christmas so we thought we'd add another
question is what do people do with unwanted gifts and surprisingly nearly half of them throw them away or sell
them so you can sort of throw in these types of questions to see unexpected
results so what did the general public do this was in Somerset House which is
in London and it's open to the public to come in there are lots of exhibitions
going on we we put a poster up outside but that was it we didn't try and lure
people to come in and say look come and use this but people were naturally curious they saw these boxes they came
in and nearly a thousand people just started answering questions and spending
between ten and twenty minutes doing this going back up to the visualisation station to see how they compared some
people just answered for two boxes and went away and others did the whole five they usually answered on their own but
then they would come back together again with whoever they were and discuss their
answers and also the questions so what did we learn from this project where we
were trying to think of a different way of asking society questions firstly that
people are very curious and they very interested in that kind of data and
secondly we didn't entice them and it was very public that they decided for
themselves to have a go they gave honest answers to the questions and that they appear to be in
the zone when they were answering them in the sense that when you go to an ATM people will sort of just be thinking
about the money that they're taking out or what they're doing there they weren't worried about leaving the state of their
physical answers for others to see no one seemed to be that bothered they they
knew that all of their answers were going to be anonymous and as I said groups discussed their answers so it was more of a two-way
process it wasn't just us collecting data from them they could think well why are they asking this question isn't this
interesting and the presentation of real-time visualizations of what everyone else had
answered proved to be a good trigger for reflection and discussion often when you
know we're asking governments ask questions or need to find something out they don't provide that feedback or give
information back to those who've given it in this case we found that it was very valuable way of getting triggering
discussion okay so that was a data from
collecting it from society the second case study I want to describe is
collecting data at home and learning a bit more about this so it's now possible
there are various smart devices to collect data about what's happening in
terms of the environment in terms of humidity light noise and so on a few
years ago there was a company that set up the smart citizen to make this an
open-source toolkit that anyone could get hold of put it into the house and
measure what they wanted not only that was that that data was then made open and available for everyone else to have
a look at and it's still there it's called smart sis and dot me and you
could just set this up in your home and then have a look at what data was being
collected but also then go around and look at what everyone else who's got one of these was also collecting and you can
see that there you have measurements in no.2 co2 and so on what we found when we
started to introduce these and provide them to peoples that they were interested for a week or so about and
the data that was being collected there go on to the website but they didn't really understand what was causing these peaks and troughs this kind of dashboard
is quite difficult to relate back to what's actually happening in their very
homes so in our project we were trying to think how can we make this more meaningful and more relevant and that people get more
interested or more curious in this type of data so what we try to do is to make
the data more tangible rather than it just being a website that you could go to and have a look at and so we built
these what are called fizzy cubes which were intended to be placed throughout
the house that would indicate certain events that were happening based on the data that was collected so the the
citizen this smart citizen device was still used to collect the data but then we developed further some ambient
displays and here's one of them is which is fizzy light and the way which it
works is that there's a simple matrix of LEDs that can be programmed to change patterns or light or pulse or brightness
this one here it was fizzy move and this cube simply has a disk on the top that
can go clockwise or anti-clockwise and it can go fast or slow so these were the
basic kit basic boxes if you like that we wanted to provide householders to
think about what they might do with those and the way in which we set it up was that they could decide what sensor
or what was being sensed to map up with a particular cube so there were four cubes for this one was head vibration
one had lights patterns one had air coming out of it and the other one was
with the rotating disc and simply you as the user can decide what's being
measured you you click on a box whether it's noise or co2 and you drag across
over to one of those four cubes and then you set up the parameters so a parameter
might be if the co2 level is equal to exhaled breath then alert me by turning
on the fizzy move cube we wanted to have these end user rules in the language
that people could understand rather than in numbers that they might not so what
happened we did a a user study in the wild we asked a number of families if they would
mind having the smart citizen and then being given the cubes so they were given
the smart system kit for a couple of weeks and just to measure what was
happening in the house and then they could go to the website to see we then gave them a physic it to see what else
they might do so what happened what were the main findings well in the first two
weeks there was curiosity about the data being collected people went and had a look at the website but then as we had
found before most people stopped looking at it even and just got on with their lives
then when we came along and gave them the physique it what we found was that
people very interested in in what these cubes might do they made lots of rules they created lots of rules between the
cubes and what was being measured and they placed them around the house most
people were really interested in noise and humidity but less interested in
gases and partly you would hope that the level of carbon monoxide or nitrogen
isn't going to go up and down that will cause your cubes to start being triggered so that's what they were
interested in to see whether they could trigger the cubes or that they would be triggered if there was a change in those
two so here are some of the types of rules they created over the period as
you can see there was a lot of diversity I'm not going to go through these in terms of what they matched that's being
measured with the type of cube I will just let this little bit's example the
fizzy light is set off to visualize the noise in the house it is placed next to the television for good visibility to

okay so you can see how different households appropriated the cubes in one
setting mum was concerned that her kids were making too much noise and so she
used it to measure how loud they were relative to others in the neighborhood but found that she was perhaps noisier
than her kids so what we found with this
way of thinking differently about how you present data to householders so that
they can be interested and curious is that using this tangible type of
representation made it accessible and that so often that the cubes themselves
when they triggered events was enough for them to understand what was happening but sometimes it made people
even more curious and that they were drilled down and looked at the website to understand a bit more about the data
and I think just taking this approach not always thinking can we try and train
up the general public to look at dashboards and and other types of visualizations suggest that we might
think of ways in which we can customize and build physical devices that show or
collect digital data in a variety of other public settings and we might think of hospitals we can think of schools
museums and parks where those communities could build these types of tangibles they don't have to be cubes
there can be other devices and so that the data that's collected and shown reflects their level of interest and
rather than always thinking as a default we should just provide dashboards of data and the bottom line here is I think
physicality can make data very visible very poignant and also it can couple for the user that where the data is coming
from and the to that event and what it means to them
so the the third case study I want to describe is thinking a bit differently
about how we can collect data at scale and it's a project that we conducted in
collaboration with people on the Madeira Island in in Portugal those of you
who've ever been there it's a very beautiful volcanic island and there are
now nearly one and a half million tourists who go there every year is quite a small island and there's only
about 250,000 people who lived there and so the the local government is concerned
about the economic ecological and and social impact they're having so many
people come to the island now they have the massive tourist ships that come true
ships that come in three or four times a day and offload thousands of people into this small island so they're worried
it's affecting the islands resources and the wildlife and so they want to have a better idea of where the tourists go
once they come off the cruise ships and also into the airports and so with some
researchers they set up an infrastructure to try and track where people go this infrastructure is a
simple passive Wi-Fi hotspot sensing system that can track where people go by
picking up the unique identifier from their smartphones it's anonymous but
what it does is it allows them to track where they go and how many you know what time and it can be then represented as
people flows and so what they're able to do is collect data that shows different
parts of the island where people went and how many and whether there was peaks
and troughs now this is okay it's quite interesting data but they were thinking this isn't
you know doesn't really help us understand what people are doing in these places and that's where we came
along in that we were asked to think about how we might enrich or annotate
this data and engage the local people and also the tourists in
contributing more and maybe even interpreting that data so would they be interested in helping to understand a
bit more about how mass tourism is affecting Madeira would they provide more information to augment the hotspot
people flow data in particular would they describe what's happening around them and their surroundings and also
would they be prepared to try and guess what these visualizations meant what was
behind the data the troughs and the peaks and if so how would we do that
what could we design and develop based on our previous projects looking at physicality that might draw in the the
tourists in a general public to give their responses and being engaged with
it so we didn't want to design another app we wanted to think a bit more about
how we could get people to come in and be interested curious and engage with
the data so this is what we built which was what nicknamed Romeo and like the
other ones we wanted to design something that was at a novel that was a human height that people would come across and
think what's that realized that it was collecting data and to be able to answer questions and the design was public
friend and a friendly interface intended again using sliders and buttons that
were easy to use and that passers-by were asked questions about themselves
the data that was collected and the surroundings and they were given the opportunity to simply say yes or no or
have open-ended questions and we thought
a lot about what types of questions we might ask people that they would be interested in but also would help to
understand a bit more about what tourists did and where they went so we asked what we called contextual
questions which is describe the people around you do they how many have
mustaches how many have wearing hats and so on we also asked what environmental
questions things like what's the current mood around here does this place feel busy to you getting a better a more richer
picture of what's happening rather than just simply numbers obviously we ask
questions do with demographics what nationality are you how often have you been to Madeira why
are you here these questions were developed in consultation with the the tourist board and the local authority as
to what might be appropriate then some questions about data why does the airport get busier from me why are there
more people in the port why is it quieter and so on we also asked a number
of factual questions what's the wettest month of the year just to see whether or not people aren't seeing sensibly and we
placed Romeo in Funchal which is the capital of Madeira near to the tourist
centre and again we didn't stand there and say come on come and answer the questions we just waited to see whether
people would walk up to it approach it and think about would I like to answer
these questions and we found again many people walked up used it whether they were in pairs whether they're in groups
or by themselves or in families and over a five-day deployment there over 500
people took decided to use it many people looked on and waited but because
people who spent often up to five minutes or more they decided not to carry on waiting but they went on so
potentially we could have had more people using it because this was in Portugal we had gave them the
opportunity to answer in English or Portuguese and so you can see that a
number of people answered in Portuguese suggesting that it wasn't just the tourists on the big ships coming from
Europe and and further afar we also
found that a lot of people just aren't suggest no but there were some who answered typed typed in their answers
and sometimes it was found that the public were more accurate than a sense
of ater so they were asked how many people each day come into the airport
and most people said 3,000 for that particular month however the actual hot
spot Wi-Fi analysis was forty one day and I said yes it was 7000 so it was possible that they
were able to be more accurate and than the automated system so this just goes
to show again how long they took to answer question some people actually came back with other members of their
group to show them and to answer more and they were also able to provide some
suggestions as to what was behind the data these data visualizations have been collected so when something like this
was presented why is the central part of French are so busy at 10 o'clock many of
them said bolo do CACO and have you've been to madeira will know that this is a
traditional Portuguese bread that's sold at that particular point and everyone who goes there to buy it just not sold
at other times again they were able to answer questions like why are there more
people at the airport on Mondays and some of them suggest it's because of
more incoming tourists or business flights why does it get busier any in
the area from May onwards again some suggested it was more events in May and
there are more tourists these are kind of fairly straightforward questions and some other ones they found more difficult but we wanted to see whether
people were prepared to have a look at visualizations and think what was going on so opening up the tourist data just
like with the previous case studies with opening up environmental data what we found was that having this physical
interactive installation was very good at attracting the public who would
approach it and then they were willing to contribute more data and they felt
comfortable doing so and they were curious about the the people flow visualizations where people were going
across the island but they were quite limited in their ability to map these to
actual events so this suggests that you know our our hope that they could become data detectives maybe not the case
because it's difficult to imagine yourself what was happening there say a
week ago or yesterday even the tourist board and the local authorities were
really excited by this approach and they came up with new questions to ask that they hadn't thought before and so too just to summarize we
think that this approach to engaging the general public in a voluntary way to
give descriptions of what they're seeing and to answer questions can generate a richer picture of what's happening on
